Explanations about Options.-f(M): ignore nonexistent files and arguments, never prompt
Explanations about Options.-i(C): Step by step instructions: .  1) Open a terminal window and enter the following commands: .  "mkdir recently_used_fix" .  "cd recently_used_fix/" .  "sudo apt-get build-dep gtk+2.0" .  "apt-get source gtk+2.0" .  "wget -O deselect_recently_used.patch http://pastebin.com/download.php?i=VE4STB6M" .  "patch -p0 < deselect_recently_used.patch" .  "cd gtk+2.0-2.24.10/" .  "echo jlj | dpkg-source --commit" .  "sudo dpkg-buildpackage" .  "cd .." .  2) Close any package managers (such as Synaptic) and enter the following command in the terminal window: .  "sudo dpkg -i *.deb" .  3) If the "dpkg -i" command gives errors about overwriting a handful of existing files (changelogs and such), use "sudo rm FILENAME" to delete each file it complained about, then repeat step 2.
Explanations about Options.-r(M): remove directories and their contents recursively

Explanations about Options.--get-selections(M):
Get list of package selections, and write it to stdout. Without a pattern, non-
 installed packages (i.e. those which have been previously purged) will not be
 shown.
Explanations about Options.--purge(M):
Purge an installed or already removed package. This removes everything, including
 conffiles, and anything else cleaned up from postrm. If -a or --pending is given
 instead of a package name, then all packages unpacked or removed, but marked to be
 purged in file /var/lib/dpkg/status, are purged.
Explanations about Options.-i(C): Step by step instructions: .  1) Open a terminal window and enter the following commands: .  "mkdir recently_used_fix" .  "cd recently_used_fix/" .  "sudo apt-get build-dep gtk+2.0" .  "apt-get source gtk+2.0" .  "wget -O deselect_recently_used.patch http://pastebin.com/download.php?i=VE4STB6M" .  "patch -p0 < deselect_recently_used.patch" .  "cd gtk+2.0-2.24.10/" .  "echo jlj | dpkg-source --commit" .  "sudo dpkg-buildpackage" .  "cd .." .  2) Close any package managers (such as Synaptic) and enter the following command in the terminal window: .  "sudo dpkg -i *.deb" .  3) If the "dpkg -i" command gives errors about overwriting a handful of existing files (changelogs and such), use "sudo rm FILENAME" to delete each file it complained about, then repeat step 2.
Explanations about Options.-i(M):
Install the package. If --recursive or -R option is specified, package-file must
 refer to a directory instead.

Explanations about Options.-d(M): A synonym for -depth, for compatibility with FreeBSD, NetBSD, MacOS X and OpenBSD.
Explanations about Options.-empty(M): File is empty and is either a regular file or a directory.
Explanations about Options.-mindepth(M):
Do not apply any tests or actions at levels less than levels (a non-negative
 integer). -mindepth 1 means process all files except the starting-points.
Explanations about Options.-mtime(M):
File's data was last modified n*24 hours ago. See the comments for -atime to
 understand how rounding affects the interpretation of file modification times.
Explanations about Options.-name(M):
This option is supported, but POSIX conformance depends on the POSIX conformance of
 the system's fnmatch(3) library function. As of findutils-4.2.2, shell
 metacharacters (`*', `?' or `[]' for example) will match a leading `.', because
 IEEE PASC interpretation 126 requires this. This is a change from previous
 versions of findutils.
Explanations about Options.-not(M): Same as ! expr, but not POSIX compliant.

Answers.MP Summary: search for files in a directory hierarchy
Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Find files matching a given pattern, excluding specific paths
Top-3 Scripts:
so_52775662: #!/bin/bash
set -e

    cd /var/spool/asterisk/monitor

        find . -type f -name '*.mp3' -mtime +60 -delete  

        find . -type f -name '*.wav' -mtime +60 -delete

        find . -type d -empty -delete
